tit.e: "Rakugo" (Traditional Comic Storytelling [or The Comic Story Itself] In Japan)
Rakugo (Japanese Traditional Comic Storytelling, or the Comic Story Itself)

sen.j: 落語（らくご）は、近世期の日本において成立し、現在まで伝承されている伝統的な話芸の一種。
sen.e: "Rakugo" refers to a kind of traditional narrative arts, established in the Japanese early modern ages and handed down to the present generation.
Rakugo is a traditional Japanese narrative art handed down through the generations that was established in early modern times.
Rakugo is a traditional Japanese narrative art handed down through the generations that was established in early modern times.

sen.j: 「落し話（おとしばなし）」、略して「はなし」とも言う。

sen.j: 都市に人口が集積することによって独立した芸能として成立した。
sen.e: The concentration of the population in urban areas enabled rakugo to become the independent performing arts.
The movement of the population to urban areas enabled rakugo to become an independent performing art.

sen.j: 成立当時はさまざまな人が演じたが、現在は通常、それを職業とする人が演じる。
sen.e: When rakugo was established, it was performed by various people having another occupation, but at present it is usually performed by the professional.
In the early days of rakugo it was performed by a variety of people having another main occupation, but at present it is usually performed by professionals.

sen.j: 衣装や道具、音曲に比較的頼らず、身振りと語りのみで物語を進めてゆく独特の演芸であり、高度な技芸を要する伝統芸能でもある。
sen.e: It is the performance peculiarly expressed in gesture and narration rather than costume, props, and music, so it needs a high-level technique as the traditional performing arts.
It is a unique performance using gesture and narration rather than costume, props, or music, and requires a high degree of skill to perform.

sen.e: It is a unique performance using gesture and narration rather than costume, props, or music, and requires a high degree of skill to perform.

sen.j: 本来「落語」とは落語家が行う演目（ネタ）のなかでも滑稽を中心とし、落ちを持つ「落とし噺」（おとしばなし）のことを指したが、現在では人情噺・芝居噺をも含めた総称として用いられる。
sen.e: Originally, rakugo meant otoshi-banashi, which is distinguished from other kinds of "neta" (programs) by its comic taste and punchline, but at present, rakugo is used as the general term for otoshi-banashi, "ninjo-banashi" (a story with human interest), and "shibai-banashi" (a story with drama).

Originally, rakugo referred to otoshi-banashi, performances which were humorous and had a punchline, but at present, rakugo is used as a general term which includes otoshi-banashi, ninjo-banashi (a story with human interest), and shibai-banashi (a story with an element of drama).

Originally, rakugo referred to otoshi-banashi, performances which were humorous and had a punchline, but at present, rakugo is used as a general term which includes otoshi-banashi, ninjo-banashi (a story with human interest), and shibai-banashi (a story with an element of drama).

sen.j: 落語は寄席（よせ）と呼ばれる常設館で演じられることが多いが、近年は若手による小さなライブもある。
sen.e: Mostly, rakugo has been performed at a storytellers' hall called "yose," and nowadays, a small live performance of rakugo by a young comic storyteller is also seen.
Mostly, rakugo has been performed at yose (storytellers' halls), but in recent years small live rakugo performances by young comic storytellers have also appeared.

sen.j: 落語家の舞台のことを「高座（こうざ）」と呼ぶ。
sen.e: The stage that a comic storyteller goes onto is called "koza" in Japanese.

sen.j: 江戸落語と上方落語には小道具や慣習に違いがある。
sen.e: "Edo rakugo" (the rakugo performed in Edo) and "Kamigata rakugo" (the rakugo performed in 'Kamigata' [Kyoto and Osaka area]) differ in props and routines.

sen.j: 江戸時代から明治ごろまでに原型が成立し、戦前までの時期に演出が確立した演目を「古典落語」とする。
sen.e: Classical rakugo refers to the programs whose prototypes were established from Edo to around Meiji period, and whose staging was established before World War Ⅱ.
Classical rakugo refers to those performances which were established in some form between the Edo and Meiji periods, and which were staged World War Ⅱ.

sen.j: それ以外の「新作落語」は、多くの場合、作者もしくは初演者以外の噺家がネタにしていることが少なく、斯界全体の共通財産となっていないことが多い。
sen.e: Programs of new rakugo have rarely been performed by storytellers - other than the creator (or the first performer) of the story - so most of the programs do not constitute the common property of the whole rakugo community.

sen.e: New rakugo has mainly been performed either by the authors themselves or young or inexperienced storytellers, and most of the performances do not constitute the common property of the whole rakugo community.

sen.e: But many of them have been characteristically quick to respond to the social trend by touching on the topical agenda or by sprinkling sarcastic spice on the story.

sen.e: Incidentally, the distinction between classical rakugo and new rakugo is not always clear, so not a few works, such as Little Flute (a new rakugo program made by the third Beicho KATSURA and performed by many storytellers), are deemed to be ambiguous in category.

sen.j: 古典落語のうち、滑稽を中心とし、噺の最後に落ちまたはサゲのあるものを「落とし噺」という。
sen.e: Of all classical rakugo, the story characterized by its comic taste and punchline (called "ochi" or "sage") is categorized as otsoshi-banashi.
sen.cmt: （注）・・・「落ち」の訳に用いた"punchline"の意味は、Longman Dictionary of Contemporary English （以下、LDCEと略記）によれば、"the last few words of a joke or story, which make it funny or surprising" （ジョークや物語の最後に添えて、聞き手を面白がらせる、あるいは意外に思わせる言葉）です。
sen.e: Within classical rakugo, stories characterized by their comic content and punchlines called "ochi" or "sage" are categorized as otoshi-banashi.
Within classical rakugo, stories characterized by their comic content and punchlines called "ochi" or "sage" are categorized as otoshi-banashi.

sen.j: 人情の機微を描くことを目的としたものを「人情噺」とする。
sen.e: The story which aims to depict subtleties of human nature is categorized as ninjo-banashi.
Stories which aim to depict the subtleties of human nature are categorized as ninjo-banashi.
Stories which aim to depict the subtleties of human nature are categorized as ninjo-banashi.

sen.j: 人情噺はたいていの場合続きものによる長大な作品で、かつては主任（トリ）に出た噺家が10日間の興行中連続して演じるものであったが、現在ではその区切りのいい一部分が取出されて演じられることが多い。
sen.e: Mostly, ninjo-banashi is a long series of works, so in the past, the feature storyteller (called "tori") performed ninjo-banashi for 10 consecutive days during the show, but nowadays, only a separable part of the works is performed in many cases.

Mostly ninjo-banashi form a long series of connected works, so in the past the central storyteller, or tori, performed a sequence of ninjo-banashi for ten consecutive days, but nowadays only individual sections of the sequence are performed in many cases.

sen.j: 「落とし噺」や「人情噺」が素で上演されるのに対して、芝居のような書割や音曲を利用し、場合によっては演者が立って芝居のごとき見得をしたりする演目を「芝居噺」という。
sen.e: Otoshi-banashi and ninjo-banashi are both performed simply with talking, but in contrst, shibai-banashi takes the staging like "shibai" (a theatrical performance), in which "kakiwari" (a stage setting) and music are used and occasionally the performer stands up and poses.

Otoshi-banashi and ninjo-banashi are both performed simply by talking, but in contrast shibai-banashi are staged like a shibai (theatrical performance or play), in which a kakiwari (stage setting) and music are used, and occasionally the performer may stands up and pose as part of the performance.

sen.e: In "Kamigata" (Kyoto and Osaka area), the music of "geza" (a background musician) is used in every genre of rakugo as "hamemono" (the musical accompaniment for stage effect) during the storytelling, but in Tokyo, it is not.
sen.cmt: （注）・・・次のセルの内容との対比から、原文の意味内容は「上方落語においては（落とし噺や人情噺など）あらゆるジャンルで一般的に音曲が利用された」、という風に解しています。
sen.e: In Kamigata rakugo (from the Kyoto and Osaka area), it is usual to include the music of a geza (background musician) in every genre of rakugo as the hamemono (musical accompaniment for stage effect) during the storytelling, but in Tokyo (Edo rakugo) it is not.

sen.j: 従って音曲噺という項目をわざわざ立てるのは江戸落語に限られる。

sen.j: 落語家身分が初めに習い覚える話を「前座ばなし」と呼ぶ。

The first stories learned by comic storytellers when they are new to rakugo are called zenza-banashi.
The first stories learned by comic storytellers when they are new to rakugo are called 'zenza-banashi.'

sen.j: 多くは口慣らしや口捌きを兼ねた単純で短い、しかし基礎的な技術を養うのに適したネタである。
sen.e: Most programs of zenza-banashi are simple and short, so they are suitable for acquiring the basic storytelling skills, and they are also used for loosening up the performer's tongue (in other words, for warming up the talk technique).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Most performances of zenza-banashi are simple and short, so they are suitable for acquiring basic storytelling skills, and they are also used for improving a storyteller's vocal technique and letting a beginner become accustomed to performing.

Most performances of zenza-banashi are simple and short, so they are suitable for acquiring basic storytelling skills, and they are also used for improving a storyteller's vocal technique and letting a beginner become accustomed to performing.

sen.j: 二つ目や真打によって演じられることもあるが、比較的簡単な軽い話とみなされるためにトリの演目になることは無い。
sen.e: Regarded as a relatively brief and light story, zenza-banashi is never played by the feature performer called tori, although played by "hutatsu-me" (the performer situated between 'zenza' [a beginner rakugo-ka] and 'shin-uchi' [a star rakugo-ka]) and by shin-uchi occasionally.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Regarded as a relatively brief and light story, zenza-banashi are never performed by established storytellers called tori, although they may be played by futatsu-me performers, situated between the zenza beginner storytellers and shin-uchi skilled performers, and occasionally by shin-uchi themselves.

sen.j: サゲの種類によるもの（落とし噺）
sen.e: Classification by the varieties of "sage" (or 'ochi') within otoshi-banashi
Classification by Type of Sage or Ochi within Otoshi-banashi
Classification by type of sage or ochi within otoshi-banashi
sen.cmt: 文頭のみ大文字にしました。

sen.j: にわか落ち、ひょうし落ち、逆さ落ち、考え落ち、まわり落ち、見立て落ち、まぬけ落ち、とたん落ち、ぶっつけ落ち、しぐさ落ちなどがある（落ちの項参照）。
sen.e: Otoshi-banashi has various kinds of sage (or ochi), such as "niwaka-ochi" (the punchline using a pun), "hyoshi-ochi" (the punchline cracked in a rhythmical story), "sakasa-ochi" (the punchline whose funny points were hinted at to the audience early on), "kangae-ochi" (the punchline whose funny points might be difficult to catch), "mawari-ochi" (the punchline that returns to the beginning of the story), "mitate-ochi" (the punchline that likens something to a different thing), "manuke-ochi" (the punchline that ends with a nonsense or an absurdity), "totan-ochi" (the punchline that makes the whole story plausible), "buttsuke-ochi" (the punchline whose characters' words are at odds with each other), and "shigusa-ochi" (the punchline using gestures) [cf. the section of "Ochi"].
sen.cmt: （注）・・・それぞれの「落ち」につき下記ブログを参照の上次のように訳しています。①「にわか落ち」・・・「しゃれを使った落ち」②「ひょうし落ち」・・・「リズミカルに進んで最後の一言でオチるもの」③「逆さ落ち」・・・「オチの理屈や内容を（観衆に）先に言っておくもの」④「まわり落ち」・・・「話が回り回って元の所に戻るもの」⑤「見立て落ち」・・・「ある物を別の物に見立てるもの」⑥「まぬけ落ち」・・・「間抜け（論理矛盾）な一言で終わるもの」⑦「とたん落ち」・・・「最後の一言で話の筋がまとまるもの」⑧「ぶっつけ落ち」・・・「（登場人物の）言っていることが互いに食い違うもの」⑨「しぐさ落ち」・・・「しぐさで落ちをつけるもの」[http://kmblog.blog55.fc2.com/blog-entry-154.html]
sen.e: Otoshi-banashi have various kinds of sage or ochi, such as niwaka-ochi (punchlines using a pun), hyoshi-ochi (forming part of a rhythmical story), sakasa-ochi (which have been hinted at to the audience early on), kangae-ochi (which might make the audience think or may be difficult to understand), mawari-ochi (which link to the beginning of the story), mitate-ochi (which liken something to a different thing), manuke-ochi (ending in nonsense or absurdity), totan-ochi (which add plausibility to the story as a whole), buttsuke-ochi (where characters' words are at odds with each other), and shigusa-ochi (using gestures) [see the article Ochi for details].

Otoshi-banashi have various kinds of sage or ochi, such as niwaka-ochi (punchlines using a pun), hyoshi-ochi (forming part of a rhythmical story), sakasa-ochi (which have been hinted at to the audience early on), kangae-ochi (which might make the audience think or may be difficult to understand), mawari-ochi (which link to the beginning of the story), mitate-ochi (which liken something to a different thing), manuke-ochi (ending in nonsense or absurdity), totan-ochi (which add plausibility to the story as a whole), buttsuke-ochi (where characters' words are at odds with each other), and shigusa-ochi (using gestures) (see the article Ochi for details).

sen.j: 必ずしも十分な分類法ではないが、現在もっとも広く用いられている。
sen.e: This is still incomplete but the most popular classification now.
While incomplete, this is the most popular current classification.
While incomplete, this is the most popular current classification.

sen.j: このほかに桂枝雀 (2代目)による四分類法（ドンデン、謎解き、へん、合わせ）がある。
sen.e: Besides, the second Shijaku KATSURA classifies otoshi-banashi according to the contents of the punchline into four categories : "donden" (the punchline which amuses the audience with its unexpected twist in an ordinary story line); "nazotoki" (the punchline that suggests the answer of a riddle given to the audience in the story); "hen"(the punchline that amuses the audience with its wanders); and "awase" (the punchline that amuses the audience by matching two different things mentioned in the story with each other).
sen.cmt: （注）・・・「ドンデン」は「話の筋に意外なひねりを加えることで聴衆を楽しませる落ち」、「謎解き」は「話の展開上聴衆が抱くであろう疑問を種明かしするタイプの落ち」、「へん」は「話を脱線させることで聴衆を楽しませるタイプの落ち」、「合わせ」は「話の中で異なる事物を合致させることにより聴衆を楽しませるタイプの落ち」と訳しています。
sen.e: In addition to the classification above, the second Shijaku KATSURA classified otoshi-banashi into four categories according to the type of punchline, namely, donden (punchlines which amuse the audience with an unexpected twist to an ordinary story line), nazotoki (that suggest the answer to a riddle presented to the audience within the story), hen (that amuses the audience by taking the story on a tangent), and awase (punchlines that amuse the audience by bringing together two separate things mentioned earlier in the story).
sen.cmt: Grammar, changed for clarity, punctuation, wording, flow.
sen.e: In addition to the classification above, the second Shijaku KATSURA classified otoshi-banashi into four categories according to the type of punchline, namely, donden (punchlines which amuse the audience with an unexpected twist to an ordinary story line), nazotoki (that suggest the answer to a riddle presented to the audience within the story), hen (that amuses the audience by taking the story on a tangent), and awase (punchlines that amuse the audience by bringing together two separate things mentioned earlier in the story).

sen.e: Besides, there exist other components of rakugo stage as well, such as "debayashi" (the background music played when a storyteller appears on stage), "kimono" (Japanese traditional clothing used by a storyteller), "zabuton" (a traditional square floor cushion for sitting on), "koza" (the stage that a storyteller goes onto) and "mekuri" (paper cards stitched together and stood on stage, and the name of a storyteller is written on the card one by one).

sen.e: Debayashi (background music played when a storyteller appears on stage), kimono (Japanese traditional clothing worn by a storyteller), zabuton (a traditional square floor cushion for sitting on), koza (the stage that a storyteller goes onto) and mekuri (paper cards stitched together and stood up on stage, the name of a storyteller written on each card) are all additional components of the rakugo stage.

Debayashi (background music played when a storyteller appears on stage), kimono (Japanese traditional clothing worn by a storyteller), zabuton (a traditional square floor cushion for sitting on), koza (the stage that a storyteller goes onto) and mekuri (paper cards stitched together and stood up on stage, the name of a storyteller written on each card) are all additional components of the rakugo stage.

sen.j: このうち特に重要なのは言葉と仕草であり、これが落語という芸の根幹を成しているといえる。

sen.e: And the most basic component of rakugo can be said the words, including those expressed in the model.
For this reason the most basic component of rakugo can be said to be the spoken words, rather than any physical element.

sen.j: 言葉の側面から見た落語には以下のような特徴が指摘できる。
sen.e: Seen from the perspetive of words, some characteristics can be pointed out for rakugo as follows.
From the perspective of words, some specific characteristics can be pointed out as follows:
From the perspective of words, some specific characteristics can be pointed out as follows:

sen.j: 地の文と会話文（対話文）で構成されているが、噺の勘所にくると会話文によってテンポよく話を進めてゆき、説明的な地の文が少なくなる（この点が話芸としての講談との相違である）。
sen.e: The story of rakugo consists of descriptive parts and conversational parts (dialogue parts), and when the story comes to the point, conversations of characters are exchanged in a bouncy rhythm, and descriptive parts become fewer; this characteristic is not seen in another art of narration called "kodan" (vaudeville storytelling).

A rakugo story consists of descriptive parts and dialog, and when the story comes to a point the conversations between the characters are exchanged in an increasingly lively rhythm and the descriptive parts become fewer; this characteristic is not seen in another narrative art called kodan (vaudeville storytelling).

A rakugo story consists of descriptive parts and dialog, and when the story comes to a point the conversations between the characters are exchanged in an increasingly lively rhythm and the descriptive parts become fewer; this characteristic is not seen in another narrative art called kodan (vaudeville storytelling).

sen.j: 地の文の省略によって伝えきれないディテール（登場人物の細かい気持の変化や感情、会話をとりまく情景）は仕草によって補われて表現される。
sen.e: The details of the descriptive parts which are difficult to narrate - a subtle change of feelings of characters, and the background situation of their feelings and conversations - are expressed by gestures as the complement to the words.

The details of the descriptive parts which are difficult to narrate, such as subtle changes in the feelings of the characters and the background to their feelings and conversations, are expressed by gestures as a complement to the spoken words.

sen.e: The details of the descriptive parts which are difficult to narrate, such as subtle changes in the feelings of the characters and the background to their feelings and conversations, are expressed by gestures as a complement to the spoken words.

sen.j: 登場人物の多寡にかかわらず全てを一人で演じ、役割わけをしない。

Regardless of the number of characters, the whole story is told by a single storyteller.

sen.j: このため声調、言葉づかい、話しかたなどによって登場人物の個性を印象づける工夫がなされる。
sen.e: Therefore, the storyteller contrives to impress the personality of the characters each by differentiating their tone of voice, choice of words, way of talking, and others.
Therefore, the storyteller contrives to convey the personality of each character by differentiating their tone of voice, choice of words, way of talking, and other factors.
Therefore, the storyteller contrives to convey the personality of each character by differentiating their tone of voice, choice of words, way of talking, and other factors.

sen.j: 会話文から地の文への移りやその逆の場面、あるいはその他大勢的な多人数の会話においては、だれの視点から語られているのか判然としない語りが存在したり、気づかない間に語りの担い手が入れ替わったりするが、それが聴衆には不自然に聞こえない。
sen.e: When a conversational part proceeds to a descriptive part in a story - and vice versa - or when the conversations among many minor characters are exchanged, some of the conversations are unclear about which character's talk it is, and the character is changed before being noticed, but they do not sound unnatural to the audience.

When a conversational part precedes a descriptive part in the story, and vice versa, or when conversations take place among many minor characters, it is unclear sometimes as to which character is speaking, and the storyteller may change character without being noticed, but this does not sound unnatural to the audience.

sen.j: 仕草
sen.e: Gestures
Gestures
Gestures

sen.j: 仕草は、落語において言葉の欠を補うための存在である。
sen.e: In rakugo, gestures are the complement to the words.
In rakugo, gestures are an important complement to the words.
In rakugo, gestures are an important complement to the words.

sen.j: すなわち演劇のように話のすべての部分について仕草が伴っているわけではなく、言葉だけでは表現しきれない部分に補足的な意味を持って仕草が付加されているのである。
sen.e: In other words, rakugo differs from the theatrical performance that is accompanied by gestures in every part of a story, so gestures in rakugo are added as the complement to words when the words have difficulties in conveying the contents of a story.

In other words, rakugo differs from theatrical performances that are accompanied by gestures in every part of the story, and gestures in rakugo are added to complement the words when it is difficult for them to convey the meaning of the story on their own.

In other words, rakugo differs from theatrical performances that are accompanied by gestures in every part of the story, and gestures in rakugo are added to complement the words when it is difficult for them to convey the meaning of the story on their own.

sen.j: もっとも「言葉だけでは表現しきれない」内容については、言葉では端的に表現できない動作や前述「言葉」の項で述べたような地の文の欠如を補うといった低次のものから、素の芸において聴衆の想像力を刺激するために付加されるきわめて高度のものまで含まれる。
sen.e: And the contents of a story, which are difficult to convey with words, range from simple ones - an action that words have difficulties in expressing straightforward, and a performance complementary to the descriptive part mentioned above in "words" - to highly artistic ones that are added as improvisations for stimulating the imagination of the audience.
sen.cmt: （注）原文に言う「素の芸において」は「即興の芸として」の意味に解しています。
sen.e: The parts of a story which are difficult to convey with words range from simple ones, such as actions that words cannot express in a straightforward way, or sections of the performance which complement the descriptive parts mentioned above, to highly artistic ones that are added as improvisation to stimulate the imagination of the audience.

sen.j: 指さす・目をつかう：落語の性質上、噺のなかに登場するモノを実際に高座に持出すことは不可能であるために、虚空を指さしたり、見たりすることで、あたかもそれらがあるかのように演じる工夫がある。
sen.e: Gestures of pointing a finger, and shifting eyes : Rakugo does not allow a storyteller to bring an object mentioned in a story onto the stage, so he or she skillfully performs as if there were the object on stage by pointing its finger at empty space, or by staring into empty space.

Pointing a finger or staring: rakugo does not allow the storyteller to bring objects mentioned in the story onto the stage, so he or she skillfully acts as if the object were on stage by pointing a finger at an empty space, or by staring at a particular point on the stage.

Pointing a finger or staring: rakugo does not allow the storyteller to bring objects mentioned in the story onto the stage, so he or she skillfully acts as if the object were on stage by pointing a finger at an empty space, or by staring at a particular point on the stage.

sen.j: 例えば「刀を抜く」という仕草の場合、扇子を柄に見立てて抜いた後、鍔元から切先まで視線を動かしながら見ると、刀の長さが観客に伝わるという口伝がある。
sen.e: For example, there exists an oral instruction within rakugo community that the gesture of drawing a sword can be well conveyed to the audience by moving a folded fan like a haft of a sword, and then by shifting eyes from an end of the fan (likened to a sword guard) straight to a point of empty space (likened to the point of a sword).

For example, there is a tradition within the rakugo community that the gesture of drawing a sword can be well conveyed to the audience by moving a folded fan like the hilt of a sword, and then by shifting the eyes from the end of the fan to a point of empty space representing the point of the sword to indicate the length of the blade.
sen.cmt: Grammar, word choice, changed for clarity.
sen.e: For example, there is a tradition within the rakugo community that the gesture of drawing a sword can be well conveyed to the audience by moving a folded fan like the hilt of a sword, and then by shifting the eyes from the end of the fan to a point of empty space representing the point of the sword to indicate the length of the blade.

sen.j: 涙を流す：主に人情噺で多く用いられる。
sen.e: A gesture of shedding tears : This gesture is often seen in ninjo-banashi;
Crying: this gesture is often seen in ninjo-banashi.
Crying: this gesture is often seen in ninjo-banashi.

sen.j: 高座に持参した湯呑みの中の茶や湯に指をつけ、その指で目の下を縦になぞる。
sen.e: a storyteller dips its finger into tea or hot water of the teacup brought onto the stage, and he or she draws a vertical line under its eyes with the finger.
The storyteller dips a finger into a cup of tea or hot water brought onto the stage, and he or she draws a vertical line under the eyes with the finger.
The storyteller dips a finger into a cup of tea or hot water brought onto the stage, and he or she draws a vertical line under the eyes with the finger.

sen.j: 厳密には話芸ではないが、食べる、飲む、歩く、走る、着るなど、登場人物の動作を、座布団の上に制限された動きで表現することも、臨場感を出す上で非常に重要な役割を果たす。
sen.e: To make the performance lively, characters' action - eating, drinking, running, dressing, and so on - expressed merely on "zabuton" plays quite a significant role in rakugo, though the action is not the art of storytelling in a strict sense.

To make the performance lively, actions such as eating, drinking, running, dressing, and so on expressed in a defined manner without moving from the zabuton play quite a significant role in rakugo, though the action is not part of the art of storytelling in a strict sense.

To make the performance lively, actions such as eating, drinking, walking, running, dressing, and so on expressed in a defined manner without moving from the zabuton play quite a significant role in rakugo, though the action is not part of the art of storytelling in a strict sense.

sen.j: 使用する道具は、原則として扇子と手ぬぐいに限られる（稀に湯呑みも使われる）。
sen.e: In principle, the props used in rakugo are only "sensu" and "tenugui," but in a rare case, a teacup is also used.
In principle, the props to be used in rakugo are limited to sensu and tenugui, but in rare cases a teacup is also used.
sen.cmt: This sentence conflicts in meaning with the sentence in cell B80 above, where five standard props are outlined. Punctuation, grammar.
sen.e: In principle, the props to be used in rakugo are limited to sensu and tenugui, but in rare cases a teacup is also used.

sen.j: 扇子と手ぬぐいは、落語の表現上抽象性があらかじめ与えられており、状況に応じて、前者は箸や刀になり、後者は財布や証文になるなど、様々な用途で使用される。
sen.e: Sensu and tenugui are given versatility in rakugo, so they are used to symbolize various things - for example, the former becomes "hashi" or a sword, and the latter becomes a wallet or a document.
sen.cmt: （注）原文に言う「抽象性」は文脈からいって「万能性・融通性」(=versatility)の意味だと解しています。
sen.e: The sensu and tenugui are given a great deal of versatility in rakugo as they are used to symbolize a range of things, for example, the former may be used to represent a pair of chopsticks or a sword, and the latter a wallet or a document.

The sensu and tenugui are given a great deal of versatility in rakugo as they are used to symbolize a range of things, for example, the former may be used to represent a pair of chopsticks or a sword, and the latter a wallet or a document.

sen.j: 扇子は落語家の符牒で「カゼ」と呼ばれ、特に幅が広く作ってある。
sen.e: Sensu is called "kaze" within the community of storytellers, and the width is a little wider than a usual sensu.
Sensu are called kaze within the community of storytellers, and the width is a little wider than a standard sensu.
Sensu are called 'kaze' within the community of storytellers, and the width is a little wider than a standard sensu.

sen.j: 刀、槍、箸、筆、キセルなど棒状の物の他に、開いた状態で手紙や提灯に見立てられる。
sen.e: When folded, sensu is used like a sword, a pike, "hashi," a writing brush, "kiseru" (a traditional Japanese cigarette pipe), or other things in a stick shape, and when unfolded, sensu is used like a letter or a paper lantern.

When folded, a sensu is used like a sword, a pike, chopsticks, a writing brush, a kiseru (traditional Japanese cigarette pipe), or other things which are long and thin, and when unfolded, the sensu is used like a letter or paper lantern.

When folded, a sensu is used like a sword, a pike, chopsticks, a writing brush, a kiseru (traditional Japanese cigarette pipe), or other things which are long and thin, and when unfolded, the sensu is used like a letter or paper lantern.

sen.j: 手ぬぐいは「マンダラ」と呼ばれる。
sen.e: Tenugui is called "mandala."
Tenugui are called mandala within the rakugo community.
Tenugui are called 'mandala' within the rakugo community.

sen.j: 財布や証文、煙草入れ、本、巾着など袋状・布状の物の他に、紐や縄として使われる。
sen.e: Tenugui is used like a wallet, a document, a cigarette case, a book, a thing of a sac shape (or a thing like cloth) including a drawstring money pouch, a string, or a rope.
A tenugui is used to represent a wallet, a document, a cigarette case, a book, any object made of cloth or in the shape of a bag, such as a drawstring money pouch, and even a string or a rope.
A tenugui is used to represent a wallet, a document, a cigarette case, a book, any object made of cloth or in the shape of a bag, such as a drawstring money pouch, and even a string or a rope.

sen.j: 上方落語ではこれらの他に見台と呼ばれる簡素な台と膝隠しが演者の前に置かれることがあるなどの特徴がある。
sen.e: Peculiarly in Kamigata-rakugo, a simple bookrack (called "kendai") and "hiza-kakushi" (a low single-leaf screen) are sometimes placed in front of a storyteller.
sen.cmt: （注）「膝隠し」は「低い衝立（ついたて）」です。[http://www.kamigatarakugo.jp/about.html]参照
sen.e: In Kamigata rakugo a simple bookrack called a kendai or a low single-leaf screen called a hiza-kakushi are sometimes placed in front of the storyteller.
In Kamigata rakugo a simple bookrack called a kendai or a low single-leaf screen called a hiza-kakushi are sometimes placed in front of the storyteller.

sen.j: 服装・効果音
sen.e: Costume and sound effects
Costume and Sound Effects
Costume and sound effects
sen.cmt: 文頭のみ大文字にしました。

sen.j: 落語家は単純な柄か無柄の和服を着用する。
sen.e: A storyteller should wear Japanese clothes with a simple or no pattern on it.
A storyteller should wear Japanese clothes with little or no pattern.
A storyteller should wear Japanese clothes with little or no pattern.

sen.j: このとき、羽織の脱ぎ方一つをとっても約束事がある。
sen.e: And here, there exist some rules - for example, the rules about when a storyteller should take off "haori" (a Japanese half coat) during rakugo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: There are also some additional rules in relation to when a storyteller should take off their haori (Japanese half coat) during the performance.
There are also some additional rules in relation to when a storyteller should take off their haori (Japanese half coat) during the performance.

sen.j: まず、演目のイントロダクションともいうべき関連した話題や背景を紹介していく枕から本題に移行する合図として、羽織を脱ぐ。
sen.e: Firstly, haori is taken off as the sign that the story progresses from "makura" (a related topic, or a background of the story, which serves as the introduction of the program) to the main topic.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Firstly, the haori is taken off to signify that the story is progressing from the makura (a related topic, or the background to the story, which serves as an introduction to the performance) to the main topic.

Firstly, the haori is taken off to signify that the story is progressing from the makura (a related topic, or the background to the story, which serves as an introduction to the performance) to the main topic.

sen.j: また大店（おおだな）などの商家を扱った演目では羽織は羽織ったままである。
sen.e: Secondly, haori is not taken off in the program that a merchant house - especially a large one - becomes the stage of the story.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Secondly, the haori is not taken off during performances where a merchant house, especially a large one, forms the focus of the story.
Secondly, the haori is not taken off during performances where a merchant house, especially a large one, forms the focus of the story.

sen.j: 八つぁん・熊さん等の名で代表される町人や職人が登場するものでは羽織を脱ぐ。
sen.e: Thirdly, haori is taken off in the program that an ordinary merchant or artisan, typically named "Hattsuan" and "Kumasan," appears.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Thirdly, the haori is taken off in performances where an ordinary merchant or artisan, typically named Hattsuan or Kumasan, appears.
Thirdly, the haori is taken off in performances where an ordinary merchant or artisan, typically named Hattsuan or Kumasan, appears.

sen.j: 更に、羽織の脱ぎ方も肩から滑らせるようにして一瞬で脱ぐ所作も注目すべき点である。
sen.e: And moreover, the storyteller's carriage is noteworthy, which slips a haori off its shoulders in a moment.
Moreover, the ability of the storyteller to slip the haori from the shoulders in a moment is also worty of note.
Moreover, the ability of the storyteller to slip the haori from the shoulders in a moment is also worthy of note.

sen.j: このような決めごとにより、観衆の耳目を自身の芸そのものに集中させる。
sen.e: Using these rules, the storyteller attracts the attention of the audience to his or her art of narration.
By adhering to these rules the storyteller attracts the attention of the audience to his or her art of narration.
By adhering to these rules the storyteller attracts the attention of the audience to his or her art of narration.

sen.j: 落語は純粋な話芸であり、演じている最中は、音曲や効果音などは制限される。
sen.e: Rakugo is a genuine art of narration, so music, sound effects, and the like are not used when a storyteller narrates the story.
In rakugo the focus is on the art of narration, so music, sound effects and the like are not used when the storyteller narrates the story.
In rakugo the focus is on the art of narration, so music, sound effects and the like are not used when the storyteller narrates the story.

sen.j: ただし地域や演目などによっては、出し物の最中に音曲や効果音が使用される場合がある。
sen.e: However, in some areas, or in some programs, music and sound effects are used even when a storyteller narrates the story.
However, in some areas, or in some specific performances, music and sound effects are used when the storyteller narrates the story.
However, in some areas, or in some specific performances, music and sound effects are used when the storyteller narrates the story.

tit.cmt: 文頭のみ大文字にしました。

sen.j: 本筋に入る前に演目に関わりのある小話が語られ、これを「枕」という。
sen.e: Before getting into the main topic, a storyteller warms up with the funny little tale that is related to the program, and the tale is called "makura."
Before getting into the main topic, a storyteller warms up with a funny little tale that is related to the performance called a makura.
Before getting into the main topic, a storyteller warms up with a funny little tale that is related to the performance called a makura.

sen.j: これの果たす役割は、小話で笑わせて、本題の前に聴衆をリラックスさせる、本題に関連する話題で聴衆の意識を物語の現場に引きつける、落ちへの伏線を張る、などが挙げられる。
sen.e: Makura has some roles in rakugo - to amuse the audience and make them relax before the start of the main topic, to lead the audience with its topic (related to the main topic) to a scene of the story, to allude to the punchline, and so on.

The makura fills a variety of roles in rakugo, such as to amuse the audience and get them to relax before the start of the main topic, to lead the audience into the main topic of the story using a related scene, or as a tool to set up the final punchline, among others.

The makura fills a variety of roles in rakugo, such as to amuse the audience and get them to relax before the start of the main topic, to lead the audience into the main topic of the story using a related scene, or as a tool to set up the final punchline, among others.

sen.j: 古典落語の演題の中には、現在では廃れてしまった風習、言葉を扱うものがあり、それらに関する予備知識がないと、話全体や落ちが充分に楽しめないことがあり、枕がこの目的にあてられることも多い。
sen.e: Some programs of classical rakugo mention the words and customs that are obsolete today, so that the audience occasionally cannot enjoy the whole story or the punchline to their hearts' content without the previous knowledge, so makura often provides the knowledge.

Some classical rakugo performances contain words and customs that are obsolete today, and the audience may not be able to enjoy the whole story or the punchline fully without previous knowledge, so the makura is often used to provide the audience with assistance in this regard.
sen.cmt: Changed for clarity, grammar, wording, punctuation.
sen.e: Some classical rakugo performances contain words and customs that are obsolete today, and the audience may not be able to enjoy the whole story or the punchline fully without previous knowledge, so the makura is often used to provide the audience with assistance in this regard.

sen.j: 本来の筋にはない、演者によって挿入されたおかしみのある部分を「くすぐり」と呼ぶ。
sen.e: And a storyteller sometimes inserts a humorous tale, which is not seen in the original plot, and the tale is called "kusuguri."
The storyteller also sometimes inserts a humorous tale which is not seen in the original plot called a kusuguri.
The storyteller also sometimes inserts a humorous tale which is not seen in the original plot called a 'kusuguri.'

sen.j: 一般的には話の筋から大きく外れないくすぐりが好まれる。
sen.e: Generally, the audience prefer the kusuguri that does not go off so far from the plot.
sen.cmt: （注）「好まれる」とあるのは「観衆から」の意味に解しています。
sen.e: Generally, audiences prefer kusuguri that are connected to the plot of the main story.
Generally, audiences prefer kusuguri that are connected to the plot of the main story.

sen.j: 本来は落し咄は落ちによって締めくくられるが、最近は口演時間（寄席では概ね一人 15 分見当）の制約や、時代的に判り難い下げが出て来たなどの関係で、本来の下げまで行かずに終ることも多い。
sen.e: In principle, otoshi-banashi should conclude with the punchline, but nowadays, it often ends before the punchline because of some snags, such as the time constraint - a storyteller has only about 15 minutes at "yose" - and the situation that some punchlines become difficult for the audience to understand in the present age.

In general, otoshi-banashi should conclude with a punchline, but nowadays they often end before the punchline because of such factors as time constraints (a storyteller generally has only about fifteen minutes on stage) and for the reason that some punchlines are difficult for modern audiences to understand.
sen.cmt: I understand 'yose' to be the building where the performance takes place, but in this sentence it appears that the stage is being indicated. Grammar, wording, punctuation.
sen.e: In general, otoshi-banashi should conclude with a punchline, but nowadays they often end before the punchline because of such factors as time constraints (a storyteller generally has only about fifteen minutes on stage) and for the reason that some punchlines are difficult for modern audiences to understand.

sen.j: 前述のように人情噺、芝居噺などのほとんどには落ちはない。
sen.e: As is mentioned above, most of ninjo-banashi and shibai-banshi have no punchline.
As mentioned above, most ninjo-banashi and shibai-banshi have no punchline.

sen.j: 他の芸能との違い
sen.e: Differences between rakugo and other performing arts
Differences between Rakugo and Other Performing Arts
Differences between rakugo and other performing arts
sen.cmt: 文頭のみ大文字にしました。

sen.j: 落語が再現芸術でありながら演劇や舞踏と一線を画して考えられるのは、演劇・舞踏といった芸能が通常扮装を伴って演技されるのに対して、落語においては扮装を排し、素のままで芸を見せるためである。
sen.e: Being the art based on a fixed model and reenacted on stage, rakugo is distinguished clearly from other performing arts, such as a theatrical performance and a dance performance, because a storyteller does not dress up as some character and shows himself or herself in its performance, while the theatrical and dance performer commonly dress up as some character.
sen.cmt: （注）「再現芸術」の意味については「定まったお手本があり、これに基づいて再現される芸術」の意味に解しています。
sen.e: Being an art based on a fixed model that is reenacted on stage rakugo can be distinguished clearly from other performing arts such as theatrical and dance performances because storytellers do not dress up as each character but rather appear as themselves, whereas theatrical and dance performers usually dress up as a character.

Being an art based on a fixed model that is reenacted on stage rakugo can be distinguished clearly from other performing arts such as theatrical and dance performances because storytellers do not dress up as each character but rather appear as themselves, whereas theatrical and dance performers usually dress up as a character.

sen.j: すなわち落語では、噺家は登場人物や話の流れに相応しい身なりや格好をモノ（衣装・小道具・大道具・書割・照明・効果音）で表現することはなく、主として言葉と仕草によって演出効果をねらう。
sen.e: In rakugo, a storyteller expresses the attire and the clothes - suitable for the character and the plot of the story - in principle, not with various stuff (costume, props, stage setting, "kakiwari," stage lighting, and sound effects), but with words and gestures.

In rakugo, storytellers convey the the attire and appearance of the characters they portray not with various physical objects such as costume, props, the stage setting, kakiwari, stage lighting, and sound effects, but with words and gestures.

In rakugo, storytellers convey the attire and appearance of the characters they portray not with various physical objects such as costume, props, the stage setting, kakiwari, stage lighting, and sound effects, but with words and gestures.

sen.j: そのために、落語の表現要素は (1) 噺家の芸に結びつく基本的な要素（言葉、仕草）と (2) 1 を助けるためにその場に応じて何にでも変化できるようなニュートラルな最低限のモノ（小道具、衣装）とに区分することができるのである。
sen.e: Accordingly, factors of expression in rakugo can be classified into two categories, that is, the basic factors (words and gestures) directly linked with the art of a storyteller, and the minimum stuff (props and costume) that complements the basic factors with its versatility.

Accordingly, methods of expression in rakugo can be classified into two categories, basic factors (words and gestures) directly linked with the art of the storyteller, and restricted tools (props and costume) that complement these basic factors through their versatility.

Accordingly, methods of expression in rakugo can be classified into two categories, basic factors (words and gestures) directly linked with the art of the storyteller, and restricted tools (props and costume) that complement these basic factors through their versatility.

sen.j: これは、素の芸であることを前提とする落語の大きな特徴であるといえるだろう。
sen.e: These factors can be said the remarkable characteristics of rakugo, which are based on the nature not to dress up as some character.
The fact that the art itself, rather than the costume or scenery, is central to the performance is the overriding characteristic of rakugo.
The fact that the art itself, rather than the costume or scenery, is central to the performance is the overriding characteristic of rakugo.

sen.j: 一人の話者が聴衆を笑わせる芸としては、ほかに漫談が挙げられる。
sen.e: In addition to rakugo, there exists another amusing, narrative art called "mandan" (comic chat) performed by one person.
In addition to rakugo there is another amusing, narrative art called mandan (comic chat) which is performed by a single person.
In addition to rakugo there is another amusing, narrative art called mandan (comic chat) which is performed by a single person.

sen.j: しかし、漫談が聴衆に語りかける話法を用いるのに対し、落語は主として登場人物同士の対話によって話が進められてゆくことがひとつの大きな特徴といえるであろう。
sen.e: Mandan takes the style of monologue, while rakugo is mostly occupied with the dialogue between the characters, which could be said a remarkable characteristic of rakugo.
Mandan is in the style of a monologue, while rakugo is mostly occupied with the dialogue between several characters, which could be said to be the remarkable characteristic of rakugo.
Mandan is in the style of a monologue, while rakugo is mostly occupied with the dialogue between several characters, which could be said to be the remarkable characteristic of rakugo.

sen.j: 枕の部分を別とすれば、落語の本筋の部分では、必要最小限の情景の叙述（「地」といわれる部分）と、演出上、話からはなれて緊張を解くなどの目的で、「語りかけ」に戻ることもあるが、主として、物語は対話で成り立っている。
sen.e: In rakugo, the main topic is mostly occupied with dialogue, and the rest is the minimum background description (called "ji") and the monologue that is diverged from the story for relaxing the audience - though the structure of the introductory part (called "makura") is different.

In rakugo the main topic centers around the dialogue between the characters, and the remainder is minimal background description (called ji) or a monologue which is separate from the main story and has the aim of relaxing the audience, though the structure of the introductory makura is different.

In rakugo the main topic centers around the dialogue between the characters, and the remainder is minimal background description (called ji) or a monologue which is separate from the main story and has the aim of relaxing the audience, though the structure of the introductory makura is different.

sen.j: 会話が少なく、主にいわゆる「地の文」で展開される話を「地噺（じばなし）」と呼ぶ（『紀州 (落語)』など）。
sen.e: The story made up of so-called descriptive parts (and few dialogues) is called "ji-banashi," exemplified by "Kishu" (Kishu Province).
Stories made up of so-called descriptive parts and few dialogues are called ji-banashi, exemplified by Kishu Rakugo.
Stories made up of so-called descriptive parts and few dialogues are called 'ji-banashi,' exemplified by "Kishu Rakugo."

tit.cmt: 文頭のみ大文字にしました。

sen.j: おもしろみのある話の源流は『竹取物語』、または『今昔物語』や『宇治拾遺集』に収められた説話にまでさかのぼる。
sen.e: The origin of comic story traces way back to the tales included in "Taketori Monogatari" (The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter), "Konjaku Monogatari" (Tales of Now and Then), and "Uji Shui-shu" (Collection of Tales from Uji).

The origin of comic story telling can be traced back to the tales included in "Taketori Monogatari" (The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter), "Konjaku Monogatari" (Tales of Now and Then), and "Uji Shui-shu" (Collection of Tales from Uji).

The origin of comic story telling can be traced back to the tales included in "Taketori Monogatari" (The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter), "Konjaku Monogatari" (Tales of Now and Then), and "Uji Shui-shu" (Collection of Tales from Uji).

sen.j: 滑稽な話を集めた本の元祖としては、誓願寺の安楽庵策伝が京都所司代の板倉重宗に語った話をもとに作られたという1623年の『醒睡笑』が挙げられる。
sen.e: The book that collected funny stories for the first time in history was "Seisuisho," which is said to have been written in A.D. 1623 by Sakuden ANRAKUAN at Seigan-ji Temple, based on the tales he spoke to Shigemune ITAKURA, the Governor-General of Kyoto.

sen.e: From this book, some stories performed even today were born, such as "Kohome" (A Flattered Baby), "Ushihome" (A Flattered Cow), and "Tonasuya-seidan" (A Pumpkin Vender).

sen.e: Encho SANYUTEI, a popular storyteller from the last days of Tokugawa shogunate to the Meiji period, was known as a historic master of storytelling, so the book (based on the shorthand notes of his storytelling) gave a great impact on the then literature - particularly, gave birth to the sentences written in a colloquial style.

sen.j: 明治時代から興行収入の歩合（割 (寄席)）だけでは生活が成り立たなくなってきた。
sen.e: From the Meiji period, some comic storytellers have had a hard time in earning their living merely by receiving their percentage of the box-office revenues.
Since the Meiji Period some comic storytellers have had a hard time in earning a living only through receiving a percentage of box-office revenues.
Since the Meiji period some comic storytellers have had a hard time in earning a living only through receiving a percentage of box-office revenues.

sen.j: スポンサー（旦那、お旦）からのお小遣いや、妻の賃労働収入をあてにしたり、落語家自身がお座敷（酒席）での余興から収入を得たりした。
sen.e: And so, they got pocket mony from their sponsors (called "danna" or "odan" in Japanese), relied on the income from wage labor of their wife, and earned money for themselves by putting on an entertaiment in a Japanese-style banquet.
Some received a stipend from sponsors called danna or odan, relied on their wives' income, or earned money for themselves by putting on entertaiment at Japanese-style banquets.
Some received a stipend from sponsors called danna or odan, relied on their wives' income, or earned money for themselves by putting on entertainment at Japanese-style banquets.

sen.j: 副業・内職・アルバイトの、収入源・額は様々である。
sen.e: What kind of a side job (an extra job, or a part-time job) is chosen - and how much money is earned - differ from person to person.
The kind of side job and how much was charged deiffered from person to person.
The kind of side job and how much was charged differed from person to person.
